data.title: PVH Corp lands on China's 'Unreliable Entity' list
data.description:
Weighed down by retaliatory actions by China’s Commerce Ministry, shares of PVH Corp (NYSE:PVH) fell to their lowest level in 15 months, trading in the red for a third consecutive day.

In the wake of U.S. trade policy enacting 10% tariffs on all products imported from China, Beijing slapped levies of 10% to 15% on certain U.S. products beginning Feb 10, including those from the parent company of Tommy Hilfiger and Calvin Klein, placing PVH (NYSE:PVH) on its “unreliable entity list.”

“China has taken necessary countermeasures in accordance with relevant laws and regulations and the basic principles of international law, which are completely justified and reasonable. Meanwhile, China has filed a lawsuit with the WTO to firmly safeguard its legitimate rights and interests,” a spokesperson for China’s embassy in the U.S. said.

Beijing specifically targeted PVH Corp (NYSE:PVH) because of the company’s refusal to source cotton from the Xinjiang region in light of widespread accusations of human rights abuses and forced labor against Uyghur Muslims. The boycott spurred China to launch an investigation into PVH (PVH) in September alleging violations of “normal market transaction principles by disrupting transactions with Chinese enterprises, organizations, or individuals and implementing discriminatory measures related to Xinjiang products.”

“We are surprised and deeply disappointed to learn of the decision from the Chinese Ministry of Commerce,” a spokesperson for PVH said in a statement cited by CNN. “In our 20 years of operating in China and proudly serving our consumers, as a matter of policy, PVH maintains strict compliance with all relevant laws and regulations and operates in line with established industry standards and practices.”

The company added it will work with Chinese authorities to resolve the situation.

data.title: Consumer data: Coca-Cola, Procter & Gamble and Sazerac impress in the latest Nielsen report
data.description:
The latest batch of Nielsen data showed some interesting trends in the consumer sector.

Coca-Cola Company (KO) led the beverage category over the four-week sales period tracked by Nielsen that ended on January 28. The Atlanta-based beverage giant saw an increase of 8.3% at the retail channels checked. The level of sales growth for Coca-Cola (KO) easily outpaced Keurig Dr Pepper (KDP), Monster Beverage (MNST), and PepsiCo (PEP). Meanwhile, Celsius Holdings (CELH) saw sales drop over the four weeks. Notably, Monster's (MNST) Bang continued its recovery.

In the beer category, Constellation Brands (STZ) saw sales growth, while Anheuser-Busch InBev (BUD) clawed back a little bit more market share from Molson Coors (TAP).

Diageo (DEO) added spirits market share over the four weeks as strong demand for Don Julio (+31%) and Crown Royal (+12%) boosted results. Sazerac also outpaced spirits peers, with its brands Southern Comfort, Buffalo Trace, and Fireball Cinnamon Whiskey showing solid demand.

Procter & Gamble (PG) and Church Dwight (CHD) were the big winners in the household products sector, with both companies seeing sales up 5.4% over the four-week period. However, sales growth was negative for Coty (COTY), Edgewell Personal Care (EPC), and Newell Brands (NWL).

Vital Farms (VITL) and BellRing Brands (BRBR) continued their strong run in the packaged food sector with double-digit sales growth recorded. Simply Good Foods (SMPL) also stood out with sales up 8.4%.

data.title: Cathie Wood: 'The AI movement has just begun'
data.description:
Cathie Wood, CEO and CIO of Ark Invest, highlighted that one of the dominant themes of 2025 will be the ongoing investment in artificial intelligence (AI). In a CNBC interview, Wood stated that "the AI movement has just begun," signaling that the transformative potential of AI is still in its early stages, with much more to come in the years ahead.

Wood also revealed a strategic shift in Ark Invest's AI focus, moving away from traditional hardware technology and placing greater emphasis on software. She noted, “We have been transitioning from hardware-centric technologies, including infrastructure, towards software,” highlighting a clear pivot in the firm's investment strategy to align with evolving market trends.

Wood also touted shares of Palantir Technologies (PLTR) as a software player in the AI world noting that it is a “very expensive stock but there is nothing like it in the software space.”

PLTR is coming off a strong fourth quarter earnings results and outlook beat expectations which has the stock up over 20% on Tuesday.

Moreover, Wood and her team are some of the biggest owners of PLTR as the stock is held in five of her six actively managed exchange traded funds.

Aside from the more obvious big tech and semiconductor world, Wood said that she believes one area of the market that AI has some of the most applications to introduce change is within the Healthcare sector.

“I think the most underappreciated application of AI is healthcare,” and spotlighted shares of Illumina (ILMN) which is a holding in the ARK Genomic Revolution ETF (BATS:ARKG) and ARK Innovation ETF (ARK).

Furthermore, see below how Woods' six actively managed exchange traded funds are trading to start off the 2025 year.

  • ARK Innovation ETF (NYSEARCA:ARKK) +8.8% YTD.
  • ARK Next Generation Internet ETF (NYSEARCA:ARKW) +9.8% YTD.
  • ARK Autonomous Technology & Robotics ETF (ARKQ) +4% YTD.
  • ARK Genomic Revolution ETF (BATS:ARKG) +12.8% YTD.
  • ARK Fintech Innovation ETF (NYSEARCA:ARKF) +11% YTD.
  • ARK Space Exploration & Innovation ETF (ARKX) +5% YTD.

data.title: Communication Services leads 2025 while Tech struggles: See SA's complete sector ranking
data.description:
The 2025 trading year has observed strong momentum, as the Communication Services sector outpaced all other S&P segments, while the once-dominant Information Technology sector has faced the steepest declines. This shift in sector performance comes amid a mixed economic backdrop in January, highlighted by robust nonfarm payrolls data, a cooler-than-expected core CPI report, a market surge driven by DeepSeek, and escalating tensions over ongoing tariff disputes.

As a result, Seeking Alpha ranked each sector of the S&P in accordance with its quant metrics. Regarding each sector, SA used the Select Sector SPDR ETFs as proxy names.

For reference, Seeking Alpha's Quant system is driven by powerful computer processing and SA's special 'Quantamental' analysis. It awards grades to stocks based on collective value, growth, profitability, earnings per share revisions, and price momentum metrics.

SA Sector Rankings

No. 11: The Real Estate Select Sector SPDR Fund ETF (XLRE), quant grade of 2.39.

No. 10: The Consumer Staples Select Sector SPDR Fund ETF (XLP), quant grade of 2.62.

No. 9: The Energy Select Sector SPDR Fund ETF (NYSEARCA:XLE), quant grade of 2.86.

data.title: Raiffeisen Bank targets 6-7% loan growth and 15.2% CET1 ratio in 2025 amid strategic reshaping
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: Raiffeisen Bank International AG (OTCPK:RAIFF) Q4 2024

Management View

  • Johann Strobl, CEO, reported group consolidated profits of €1.157 billion, reflecting a significant year-on-year decline due to provisions in Russia and the €824 million impact from the Belarus sale. Excluding Russia and Belarus, consolidated profits for the core group stood at €975 million, with a return on equity of 15%, slightly exceeding guidance.
  • Loans to customers increased by 3% in 2024, while net interest income was flat at €4.155 billion. Fee income grew by 5% to €1.804 billion. Operating expenses finished at €3.3 billion, resulting in a cost-income ratio of 52.5%.
  • A dividend proposal of €1.1 per share was announced, slightly lower than the previous year, reflecting the group's effort to offer shareholders consistent returns despite headwinds.
  • CFO Hannes Mosenbacher highlighted risk costs at 27 basis points for the core group, below the 35 basis points guidance, and noted €370 million in overlays available for 2025.

Outlook

  • Management expects net interest income to remain stable in 2025, with fee income seeing further improvements. Operating expenses are projected around €3.45 billion, maintaining a cost-income ratio of 52.5%.
  • Loan growth for 2025 is targeted at 6-7%, driven by stronger performance in key markets such as Slovakia, Romania, and Czechia.
  • The CET1 ratio, excluding Russia, is projected to stabilize at 15.2% by the end of 2025, supported by Basel IV implementation.
  • CEO Strobl outlined expectations for profitability at around 10% in 2025, with potential for 13% return on equity once legacy litigation issues in Poland are resolved.

Financial Results

  • Group consolidated profits fell year-on-year due to the €824 million impact from the Belarus sale and litigation provisions in Poland. For the core group, excluding Russia and Belarus, profits remained stable at €975 million.
  • Fee income grew by 5% year-on-year to €1.804 billion, supported by strong seasonal performance across key markets and product lines in Q4.
  • Net interest income was stable at €4.155 billion, with slight positive contributions from Austria and Czech Republic offsetting headwinds.
  • Loans to customers increased by 3%, with strong trends in corporate lending in Austria and stable retail portfolios, particularly in Slovakia and Czech Republic.
  • Liquidity remained robust, with a CET1 ratio of 15.1% for the core group, excluding Russia.

Q&A

  • Benoit Petrarque, Kepler Cheuvreux: Questioned updates on the Russia exit process. CFO Mosenbacher stated that legal proceedings in Russia are delaying potential deals, although discussions with interested parties continue. CEO Strobl added that complexities around equity valuation and legal constraints are key hurdles.
  • Riccardo Rovere, Mediobanca: Asked about the potential to extract dividends from Russian operations. CEO Strobl expressed skepticism about regulatory approval for dividends given current constraints.
  • Paul Fenner, Societe Generale: Inquired about provisions related to the Russian court case. CEO Strobl explained that the €800 million provision reflects current valuation assumptions and legal uncertainties, with further developments contingent on court outcomes.
  • Simon Nellis, Citi: Queried the rationale behind the €1.1 dividend proposal. CEO Strobl emphasized the importance of maintaining a CET1 ratio above the 14.5% target, given ongoing uncertainties.

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts expressed skepticism and concern, particularly regarding the ongoing challenges in Russia and the impact of litigation provisions in Poland. Questions focused on the pace of business reduction and potential financial risks.
  • Management maintained a cautiously optimistic tone during prepared remarks but displayed a defensive posture in addressing analyst concerns, particularly regarding Russia. CEO Strobl consistently reiterated the group’s compliance efforts and commitment to derisking.
  • Compared to the previous quarter, management's tone reflected a slight increase in confidence, particularly regarding the core group's performance and outlook.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • Guidance for profitability and loan growth has improved, with 2025 targets reflecting higher confidence in operational stability.
  • Strategic focus has shifted further towards derisking the Eastern European footprint, with the closure of the Belarus sale and continued reduction of Russian operations.
  • Analyst questions in the current quarter were more focused on legal and regulatory risks, reflecting heightened concerns compared to the prior period.
  • Management's tone showed a slight improvement in confidence, particularly regarding fee income growth and CET1 ratio stability.

Risks and Concerns

  • Legal proceedings in Russia, including the €244 million court ruling and related provisions, pose significant uncertainties.
  • Litigation provisions in Poland continue to weigh on profitability, though management expects some relief in 2025.
  • Challenges in exiting Russia are compounded by regulatory constraints and equity valuation complexities.
  • Macroeconomic weaknesses in Austria and Germany, combined with geopolitical risks, remain ongoing concerns.

Final Takeaway

Raiffeisen Bank International's Q4 2024 performance reflects a stable core group despite external challenges, including legal provisions and the Belarus sale impact. Management provided a cautiously optimistic outlook for 2025, targeting 6-7% loan growth, a 15.2% CET1 ratio, and stable net interest income. However, ongoing litigation and geopolitical tensions remain critical risks to monitor. Investors will likely focus on the group's ability to navigate these challenges while maintaining operational resilience and profitability.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript

data.title: PepsiCo targets low single-digit organic sales growth for 2025 amid selective investments
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: PepsiCo (NASDAQ:PEP) Q4 2024

Management View

  • CEO Ramon Laguarta highlighted significant reinvestments in Frito-Lay during Q4, funded by one-time gains, with a focus on creating infrastructure to capitalize on opportunities in 2025. He mentioned addressing both value and premium segments through better price pack architecture and investments in innovation for untapped spaces, particularly in away-from-home opportunities.
  • Laguarta emphasized the growth of PepsiCo's international business, now almost a $40 billion operation, which remains accretive to margins and represents a significant growth driver.
  • CFO Jamie Caulfield noted a 3-point foreign exchange headwind due to a stronger dollar, primarily impacting regions like Mexico. He also cited increased net interest expenses and pension expenses as factors affecting the 2025 financial outlook.

Outlook

  • Management issued low single-digit organic sales growth guidance for 2025, reflecting a cautious stance amid global uncertainty and geopolitical factors. They anticipate gradual improvement in North America performance as the year progresses, supported by innovation, away-from-home expansion, and pricing strategies.
  • Laguarta stated that while global unemployment levels are low and inflation appears to be improving, the company remains cautious due to persistent volatility, including geopolitical risks.
  • The company plans to continue systematic productivity programs such as automation, digitalization, and simplification to drive profitability while maintaining flexibility for reinvestments.

Financial Results

  • PepsiCo reported a Q4 adjusted EPS of $1.94, aligning with analysts’ expectations. Revenues were $27.89 billion, also meeting estimates.
  • Frito-Lay North America experienced a sequential decline in volumes but saw reinvestments aimed at boosting future growth. The beverages business in North America showed continued margin improvement, aligning with the company's mid-teens margin aspirations for this segment.
  • International markets contributed significantly, with particular strength in Southeast Asia, India, and Brazil. However, softer performance in China, Mexico, and parts of Western Europe, as well as geopolitical challenges in the Middle East, presented headwinds.

Q&A

  • Lauren Lieberman, Barclays: Questioned the ROI of Frito-Lay reinvestments given sequential volume declines. Jamie Caulfield responded that investments were aimed at building momentum for 2025, supported by productivity savings.
  • Bonnie Herzog, Goldman Sachs: Asked about EPS guidance flexibility and investment levels. Laguarta explained the cautious guidance reflects geopolitical risks, while investments are focused on price pack architecture and long-term growth.
  • Steve Powers, Deutsche Bank: Probed whether Frito-Lay pricing could turn negative. Laguarta clarified that the strategy involves surgical price-pack adjustments rather than outright pricing reductions.
  • Robert Moskow, TD Cowen: Inquired about the impact of GLP drugs on salty snack consumption. Laguarta stated no material impact yet, though heightened health awareness among consumers is accelerating portfolio evolution.

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts expressed cautious optimism, focusing on concerns about Frito-Lay's ROI, pricing strategies, and category growth sustainability. Sentiment leaned skeptical but constructive.
  • Management maintained confidence during prepared remarks, emphasizing long-term opportunities and resilience. However, responses during Q&A became more defensive, particularly around Frito-Lay investments and pricing strategies.
  • Compared to the previous quarter, management's tone was slightly more cautious, reflecting a volatile macroeconomic backdrop.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • Guidance shifted from 4% organic revenue growth in Q3 to low single digits for Q4, emphasizing a more conservative outlook for 2025.
  • Management reiterated confidence in long-term category growth but emphasized short-term tactical adjustments, particularly in North America.
  • Analysts continued to focus on Frito-Lay's performance, with recurring concerns about pricing and ROI on investments.
  • Management's tone remained consistent in highlighting productivity initiatives but showed increased caution regarding geopolitical and consumer uncertainties.

Risks and Concerns

  • Macroeconomic volatility and geopolitical risks were highlighted as significant challenges. Management acknowledged the impact of a strong dollar and potential government decisions on operations.
  • Analysts raised concerns about category growth sustainability, pricing strategies, and the ROI of Frito-Lay reinvestments.
  • Management pointed to productivity programs and portfolio evolution as key mitigation strategies but acknowledged near-term pressures.

Final Takeaway

PepsiCo presented a cautious yet optimistic outlook for 2025, emphasizing low single-digit organic sales growth supported by reinvestments in Frito-Lay, international expansion, and margin improvements in North America beverages. While management expressed confidence in long-term growth drivers, analysts remained concerned about the short-term ROI of investments and the sustainability of category growth amid a volatile macroeconomic environment.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript

data.title: Oaktree Specialty Lending Q1 results hurt by lower interest income, investment on non-accrual
data.description:
Oaktree Specialty Lending (NASDAQ:OCSL) stock dropped 3.0% in Tuesday morning trading after the business development company's quarterly total investment income missed the Wall Street consensus as interest income declined and due to the impact of several investments on non-accrual status.

Fiscal Q1 adjusted net investment income per share of $0.54, meeting the consensus estimate, slipped from $0.55 in the prior quarter, as adjusted total investment income dropped and operating expenses rose, partly offset by lower interest expense and lower management and Part I incentive fees.

"We had several positive outcomes within the portfolio, but continued to face challenges with several names," said CEO and Co-Chief Investment Officer Armen Panossian. We remain focused on our underperforming borrowers, working through each situation to identify the appropriate course of action.

Missing the consensus of $91.9M, adjusted total investment income for the quarter ended Dec. 31, 2024, decreased to $87.1M from $94.7M in the prior quarter, driven by lower interest income due to declines in reference rates, the impact of certain investments placed on non-accrual status, a smaller investment portfolio, lower dividend income, and lower fee income from a decrease in prepayment fees.

Net asset value per share of $ at Dec. 31, 2024 rose/fell from $18.09 at Sept. 30.

Oaktree Specialty (NASDAQ:OCSL) originated $198.1M of new investment commitments and received $352.4M of proceeds from prepayments, exits, other paydowns, and sales during the quarter. The weighted average yield on new debt investments was 9.6%.

As of Dec. 31, 2024, the company had nine investments on non-accrual status, which represented 5.1% of the debt portfolio at cost and 3.9% of the debt portfolio at fair value. That compared with nine investments on non-accrual, representing 4.9% of cost and 4.0% of the portfolio's fair value, as of Sept. 30, 2024.

On Jan. 31, 2025, Oaktree Specialty (OCSL) and Oaktree Capital I LP, an affiliate of its adviser, entered a purchase agreement under which Oaktree Capital I purchased 5,672,149 OCSL shares on Feb. 3 for $100.0M. The shares were sold at the company’s net asset value per share as of Jan. 31, 2025, which was $17.63 per share, representing a 10% premium to the stock's closing price on Jan. 31, 2025.

Conference call at 11:00 AM ET.

data.title: Sun Country Airlines projects Q1 2025 revenue of $330M-$340M with 7%-9% block hour growth
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: Sun Country Airlines (NASDAQ:SNCY) Q4 2024

Management View

  • CEO Jude Bricker emphasized the company’s diversified business model, which combines scheduled service, charter, and cargo operations to deliver flexibility and mitigate external shocks. He highlighted agreements in principle with unions for flight attendants and dispatchers, expected to improve work conditions.

  • The company took delivery of its first cargo aircraft from a new agreement with Amazon, with plans to grow the cargo fleet to 20 aircraft by summer 2025. Cargo revenue is projected to double within the next year.

  • Bricker also noted progress in scheduled service TRASM, which increased nearly 5% in December and January, signaling positive demand trends. He expects continued improvement in unit revenues.

  • CFO Dave Davis reported Q4 2024 total revenue of $260.4 million and an adjusted operating margin of 10.6%, both record highs for the company. Adjusted diluted EPS for the year stood at $1.05, and full-year revenue reached $1.08 billion. He stated that cargo and charter revenues were key drivers of growth.

  • Davis also highlighted disciplined cost management, with full-year adjusted CASM increasing only 1.3% year-over-year. He expects ex-fuel operating expenses to align with a 9%-10% block hour increase in 2025.

Outlook

  • Management forecasts Q1 2025 total revenue between $330 million and $340 million, supported by 7%-9% block hour growth. Operating margin is expected to range from 17% to 21%.

  • Scheduled service ASMs are anticipated to grow 7% in Q1 2025, while unit revenues are projected to remain flat year-over-year.

  • Cargo operations are poised for sharp growth as eight additional Amazon aircraft are integrated by late summer. Revised Amazon contract rates will escalate throughout 2025, fully taking effect in the second half.

Financial Results

  • Q4 2024 total revenue of $260.4 million exceeded analysts' estimates of $258 million. Adjusted operating margin reached 10.6%, driven by a 6.1% increase in total revenue compared to the prior year.

  • Cargo revenue grew 13.1% year-over-year to a quarterly high of $28.6 million, with revenue per block hour up 16%. Charter revenue also rose 2.3% to $48 million, bolstered by a 27% increase in ad hoc charter revenue.

  • Full-year 2024 operating margin was 9.9%, while adjusted operating margin reached 10.4%, demonstrating operational resilience despite industry overcapacity.

Q&A

  • Ravi Shanker, Morgan Stanley: Asked about the impact of strong European demand on Sun Country. CEO Bricker stated that while the airline doesn’t operate in Europe, capacity reallocation to transatlantic markets benefits Sun Country, positively affecting domestic demand.

  • Duane Pfennigwerth, Evercore: Inquired about booking patterns and capacity adjustments. Bricker explained that holding capacity further out and stabilizing pricing resulted in higher fares and slightly lower load factors.

  • Brandon Oglenski, Barclays: Asked about network priorities for summer 2025. Bricker highlighted plans to reduce marginally performing markets and improve yields through capacity adjustments.

  • Catherine O’Brien, Goldman Sachs: Questioned the impact of new labor agreements and fuel costs on Q1 margins. Davis expressed confidence in achieving strong first-quarter results despite these factors.

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts expressed cautious optimism, with questions focusing on capacity adjustments, margin resilience, and growth in cargo operations. Concerns about competitive capacity and seasonal demand were evident.

  • Management maintained a confident tone, emphasizing operational flexibility and growth opportunities, particularly in cargo. Statements like "we are confident in that guidance" and "we expect fares to be substantially higher" underscored their positive outlook.

  • Compared to the previous quarter, analysts were more focused on strategic growth areas, while management exhibited increased confidence in navigating capacity rationalization and industry dynamics.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • Guidance language shifted from emphasizing modest capacity increases in Q3 to highlighting significant cargo growth and strategic capacity reductions in Q4.

  • Scheduled service TRASM trends improved, with Q4 seeing a flat year-over-year performance compared to steep declines earlier in 2024.

  • Analysts shifted their focus from overcapacity concerns in Q3 to strategic opportunities in cargo and network optimization in Q4.

  • Management's tone appeared more confident, driven by record financial results and positive demand trends.

Risks and Concerns

  • Management acknowledged competitive pressures in certain markets but emphasized strategic capacity reductions to sustain profitability.

  • Analysts raised concerns about seasonal demand variability and potential disruptions from cargo fleet integration.

  • Mitigation strategies include leveraging the diversified business model and maintaining operational discipline.

Final Takeaway

Sun Country Airlines delivered record financial results in Q4 2024, driven by robust growth in its cargo and charter segments. Management projects strong performance in 2025, supported by capacity rationalization, cargo fleet expansion, and improved unit revenues. While analysts raised questions about competitive and seasonal challenges, the company’s diversified business model and strategic adjustments position it well for sustained profitability and growth.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript

data.title: Cheap put candidates to consider in the case of a Europe tariff – Barclays
data.description:
Uncertainty around a possible tariff to the European markets by President Trump is not off the table amid the tariff announcements over the weekend causing material market volatility.

European equities (NYSEARCA:VGK), (IEV), (IEUR), (FEZ), (STOXX) especially autos – down 4% at one point – technology, and basic resources fell considerably around the fears that the European Union could be next, said Stefano Pascale, head of equity derivatives strategy at Barclays, in a note.

“Markets are likely to remain highly sensitive to tariff developments, making it crucial to monitor risks and hedge against potential selloffs,” he said. “The fall was arguably from exposure to the global economy (including Mexico, Canada, and especially China) but also from fears around 'who's next', as Trump hinted that Europe could be a potential target as well.”

To hedge against stocks or sectors that are sensitive to headlines around tariffs, analysts identified cheap put candidates on European Union stocks that are exposed in the case of a tariff announcement.

Here are the put candidates:

  • Adidas AG (OTCQX:ADDYY) – Volatility score: 12; Implied three-month vol: 27%; Skew three-month percentile two-year: 8%
  • VAT Group AG (OTCPK:VACNY) – Volatility score: 38; Implied three-month vol: 35%; Skew three-month percentile two-year: 18%
  • Mercedes-Benz Group AG (OTCPK:MBGAF) – Volatility score: 42; Implied three-month vol: 27%; Skew three-month percentile two-year: 16%
  • Kuehne + Nagel International AG (OTCPK:KHNGF) – Volatility score: 42; Implied three-month vol: 24%; Skew three-month percentile two-year: 35%
  • LVMH Moët Hennessy - Louis Vuitton, Société Européenne (OTCPK:LVMHF) – Volatility score: 49; Implied three-month vol: 27%; Skew three-month percentile two-year: 10%

  • BMW (OTCPK:BMWKY) – Volatility score: 59; Implied three-month vol: 29%; Skew three-month percentile two-year: 22%
  • Ferrari N.V. (RACE) – Volatility score: 64; Implied three-month vol: 26%; Skew three-month percentile two-year: 12%
  • Pernod Ricard SA (OTCPK:PDRDF) – Volatility score: 76; Implied three-month vol: 30%; Skew three-month percentile two-year: 4%

data.title: Atkore plunges after management slashes forward guidance
data.description:
Atkore’s (NYSE:ATKR) stock on Tuesday sank as much as 20% after the maker of electrical equipment slashed its estimate for yearly operating earnings because of weaker demand.

Management revised its forecast to $5.75 to $6.85 a share from a prior estimate of $7.80 to $8.90 a share for the year ended in September. The average estimate among Wall Street analysts was $8.38 a share.

As for its fiscal quarter ended in December, earnings were $46.3 million, or $1.31 a share, down from $138.4 million, or $3.61 a share, a year earlier.

The results beat the consensus estimate of $1.24 a share.

Sales fell 17% from a year earlier to $661.6 million, missing the consensus estimate of $680.8 million. Its electrical unit saw revenue drop 22% to $465.4 million.

“Atkore’s first quarter results were in line with the projections for net sales, adjusted ebitda and adjusted diluted EPS we presented in November,” Bill Waltz, president and chief executive of Atkore (NYSE:ATKR), said in a statement.
